title: Aram ever actually going to be all random?
body:
Like, gets tiresome seeing aram only accounts getting all the best characters while I'm at a disadvantage on my main account simply because I own all the League champions.

It's suppose to be all random all mid yet and yet it's not nearly as random if you barely own any champions.

I don't play aram, I hate it because it's stupid and unfair because what I stated, but unfortunately my newbie bronze friends drag me a lot there and it's a chore every time.

They should just make ALL champions available in ARAM like one for all and you get one at random. This will make all the hard work of ARAM only accounts be ruined which makes me laugh :D. Also, make it so that everyone has only one (two can be debated, just an idea) reroll available every game.

It's adjusted for champions owned a little; the rate at which you get rerolls increases sharply as the number of champions you own increases. (Every game gets you 30 points base plus the number of champions you own).
the problem is that if you only own 10 champs and they're all broken OP in ARAM, you're very unlikely to need rerolls.

The free rotation is also available in ARAM; in the scenario you proposed, this means that In the long run, you'll get one of the champions you own around 54% of the time, once rerolls are taken into account. I'm not saying that owning all the broken champs is a good thing to do, but it's probably not as bad as you're picturing.

If you're interested in the math, the chance of getting  a champion you own in ARAM is
(Chance of getting a champion you own) + (Chance of getting a free week champion)*(Percent of games you can reroll)*(Chance of getting a champion you own off of a reroll)
or
(x/(x+10)) + (10/(x+10))*((x+30)/250)*(x/x+10)
where X is the number of champions you own. The equation breaks down a little as the number of champions owned gets higher (since there could be overlap between free week and owned and accommodating for that makes the equation more trouble than it's worth) but it's good for the parts of the scale you're interested in. Plus there really aren't more than maybe 10 really S-Tier picks in ARAM, so the effect drops off as you go.

The problem is that someone with only 10 champs unlocked that are all S-Tier picks in ARAM has an astronomically higher chance of getting an S-Tier pick than someone like me, who owns the entire cast (and has enough IP in the bank to unlock the new ones as soon as they come out for the next 8 champ releases...). It makes ARAM really un-fun because players who have invested the time and unlocked the champions to trade in games/try them out are constantly playing really bad stuff or trying to get rerolls/trades/etc to work out......

Well, basically, 54% of the time starts to sound REALLY great when there are 130something members of the cast.

I mean, I own a majority of the champions (mostly lacking the newer ones and the ones I don't like, like Olaf and Rammus), and ever since the introduction of snowball, pretty much everything is playable. There are champions I don't LIKE, but it's not because they're horrible in ARAM.

Honestly, it's a trade-off: do you want to be playing against someone who gets Lux more often than you do, or do you want to be playing with someone who's never played a game of Zed in their lives?

Facts: Aside a couple exceptions like Galio, win rates have not changed at all with the introduction of snowball. Ranged champions still win almost twice as much as melee champions.

Explanation: Most melee champions already have a dash, dashing in has never really been an issue. Turning that dash into a net gain for your team, either through the form of an objective, or a clean ace that results in the gain of an objective is how you win games, and snowball doesn't help you accomplish that. 9 times out of 10, when you snowball someone you a) die because you are now outnumbered and out of position far away from your team b) dive a turret as a team and die to said turret. Both options result in you trading kills at best, and feeding at worst and neither result gets you any closer to the victory screen.

First of all, do you have a source for that?

Anyone who says that snowball didn't make more champions fine in ARAM didn't play before it was a thing. Snowball is not going to fix all of a champion's problems: traditionally weak picks like Evelynn, Elise, and Udyr struggle because they're bad in 5v5 teamfights, or else they have kits that just aren't suited to the mode, like Rek'Sai or Bard. It would take a change of a titanic scale to shake up the very top and bottom of the list: certain champion archetypes are going to dominate in ARAM, and others will do poorly. But Mark/Dash had a huge impact on low-range engagers and mages like Maokai, Galio, Kennen, Vladimir, and so on. When the spell was added, Maokai and Sion actually knocked Varus and Sona (before her massive overbuffs lol) out of the top 10.

If by source you mean current win rates, you can look at any website like lolking or op.gg. If you mean win rates before/after snowball, not sure if you can find that. I only have my words to back me up hah. I have been playing ARAM ever since it was a thing in custom games back then and before Riot stepped in with an official queue, I'm kinda familiar with the map. I remember looking at win rates now and then before taking over one year break from the game, I only came back earlier this year.

The only champions that benefited from snowball are champions without innate dash to begin with, but with actual killing power, so when they finally dash in with snowball, stuff happens. IE= R magnet: Talon, Fiddlesticks, Galio, Kennen, Alistar, Karthus.. and half of these are still very mediocre today, simply because dashing in, now and then is not enough to win games. You need the individual strengths I described above.

Maokai has always been strong, and Sion, snowball happened around the time he got his rework so I can't really tell, but it's most likely the same as Maokai, press R > stick in > be forever annoying and kill stuff. These 2 champions are only strong because they counter the current meta dominated by ranged champions. Both are a pain to deal with as a ranged champion, they are sticky, beefy and deal lotta damage, with or without snowball.
